formulas.name: Cost Variance

variables.name: Earned Value
variables.description: The value of work completed

variables.name: Actual Cost
variables.description: The actual cost incurred for the work

formulas.description: Cost Variance measures the difference between the earned value and the actual cost. A positive value indicates under budget, negative indicates over budget.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to track cost performance and determine if the project is over or under budget at any point.

example.scenario: Your project has EV = $50,000 and AC = $55,000. Calculate CV.

formulas.name: Schedule Variance

variables.name: Earned Value
variables.description: The value of work completed

variables.name: Planned Value
variables.description: The authorized budget for the scheduled work

formulas.description: Schedule Variance measures the difference between earned value and planned value. A positive value indicates ahead of schedule, negative indicates behind schedule.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to track schedule performance and determine if the project is ahead or behind schedule.

example.scenario: Your project has EV = $50,000 and PV = $60,000. Calculate SV.

formulas.name: Cost Performance Index

variables.name: Earned Value
variables.description: The value of work completed

variables.name: Actual Cost
variables.description: The actual cost incurred for the work

formulas.description: Cost Performance Index measures cost efficiency. CPI > 1 means under budget, CPI < 1 means over budget, CPI = 1 means on budget.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to evaluate cost efficiency and forecast project performance.

example.scenario: Your project has EV = $50,000 and AC = $55,000. Calculate CPI.

formulas.name: Schedule Performance Index

variables.name: Earned Value
variables.description: The value of work completed

variables.name: Planned Value
variables.description: The authorized budget for the scheduled work

formulas.description: Schedule Performance Index measures schedule efficiency. SPI > 1 means ahead of schedule, SPI < 1 means behind schedule, SPI = 1 means on schedule.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to evaluate schedule efficiency and forecast project completion.

example.scenario: Your project has EV = $50,000 and PV = $60,000. Calculate SPI.

formulas.name: Estimate at Completion (BAC/CPI)

variables.name: Budget at Completion
variables.description: Total authorized budget for the project

variables.name: Cost Performance Index
variables.description: The current cost performance index

formulas.description: Estimate at Completion when current cost performance is expected to continue. Assumes the CPI trend continues for the rest of the project.
formulas.whenToUse: Use when the cost performance to date is expected to continue for the remainder of the project.

example.scenario: Project BAC = $100,000 and current CPI = 0.91. Calculate EAC.

formulas.name: Estimate to Complete (EAC - AC)

variables.name: Estimate at Completion
variables.description: Expected total cost at project completion

variables.name: Actual Cost
variables.description: The actual cost incurred to date

formulas.description: Estimate to Complete calculates the expected cost to finish all remaining work. It's the difference between EAC and AC.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to determine how much more money is needed to complete the project.

example.scenario: Project EAC = $109,890 and AC = $55,000. Calculate ETC.

formulas.name: Variance at Completion

variables.name: Budget at Completion
variables.description: Total authorized budget for the project

variables.name: Estimate at Completion
variables.description: Expected total cost at project completion

formulas.description: Variance at Completion predicts the budget surplus or deficit at project end. Positive VAC means under budget, negative means over budget.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to forecast the final budget variance at project completion.

example.scenario: Project BAC = $100,000 and EAC = $109,890. Calculate VAC.

formulas.name: To-Complete Performance Index

variables.name: Budget at Completion
variables.description: Total authorized budget for the project

variables.name: Earned Value
variables.description: The value of work completed

variables.name: Actual Cost
variables.description: The actual cost incurred to date

formulas.description: To-Complete Performance Index indicates the efficiency needed to complete the project on budget. TCPI > 1 means harder work needed; TCPI < 1 means easier.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to determine the required cost performance for the remaining work to meet the budget.

example.scenario: Project BAC = $100,000, EV = $50,000, AC = $55,000. Calculate TCPI.

formulas.name: Present Value

variables.name: Future Value
variables.description: The amount of money in the future

variables.name: Interest Rate
variables.description: The discount or interest rate (as decimal)

variables.name: Number of Periods
variables.description: The number of time periods

formulas.description: Present Value calculates the current worth of a future sum of money, discounted at a specific rate. Used for comparing costs/benefits over time.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to evaluate the time value of money and compare cash flows at different points in time.

example.scenario: You will receive $10,000 in 3 years. If the discount rate is 5%, what is the present value?

formulas.name: Net Present Value

variables.name: Cash Flows
variables.description: Series of cash inflows for each period (comma-separated)

variables.name: Discount Rate
variables.description: The discount rate (as decimal)

variables.name: Initial Investment
variables.description: The initial investment amount

formulas.description: Net Present Value calculates the present value of all future cash flows minus the initial investment. Positive NPV means profitable investment.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to evaluate project profitability and compare investment opportunities.

example.scenario: Project requires $50,000 investment. Returns $20,000, $25,000, $30,000 over 3 years. Discount rate 8%.

formulas.name: Internal Rate of Return

variables.name: Cash Flows
variables.description: All cash flows including initial investment as negative (comma-separated)

formulas.description: Internal Rate of Return is the discount rate that makes NPV equal zero. Higher IRR indicates more attractive investment.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to compare the profitability of different projects or investments.

formulas.name: Activity Duration (PERT)

variables.name: Pessimistic
variables.description: Worst-case scenario estimate

variables.name: Most Likely
variables.description: Most realistic estimate

variables.name: Optimistic
variables.description: Best-case scenario estimate

formulas.description: PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) estimates activity duration using weighted average of optimistic, most likely, and pessimistic estimates.
formulas.whenToUse: Use when there's uncertainty in activity duration estimates to get a weighted average.

example.scenario: Optimistic = 5 days, Most Likely = 10 days, Pessimistic = 20 days. Calculate expected duration.

formulas.name: Activity Variance (PERT)

variables.name: Pessimistic
variables.description: Worst-case scenario estimate

variables.name: Optimistic
variables.description: Best-case scenario estimate

formulas.description: PERT Variance measures the uncertainty or spread in activity duration estimates. Used in critical path probability analysis.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to calculate the standard deviation of project duration and assess probability of completion.

example.scenario: Optimistic = 5 days, Pessimistic = 20 days. Calculate variance.

formulas.name: Float / Slack

variables.name: Late Start
variables.description: Latest time an activity can start without delaying project

variables.name: Early Start
variables.description: Earliest time an activity can start

variables.name: Late Finish
variables.description: Latest time an activity can finish without delaying project

variables.name: Early Finish
variables.description: Earliest time an activity can finish

formulas.description: Float (or Slack) is the amount of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the project. Critical path activities have zero float.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to identify flexible activities and manage schedule risks.

example.scenario: Activity has ES = 5, LS = 8, EF = 12, LF = 15. Calculate float.
example.solution: Float = LS - ES = 8 - 5 = 3 days (or LF - EF = 15 - 12 = 3 days)

formulas.name: Communication Channels

variables.name: Stakeholders
variables.description: Number of stakeholders or team members

formulas.description: Communication Channels calculates the number of potential two-way communication paths among stakeholders. Adding stakeholders dramatically increases channels.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to plan communication requirements and assess the complexity of stakeholder interactions.

example.scenario: A project team has 10 stakeholders. How many communication channels exist?

formulas.name: Expected Monetary Value (EMV)

variables.name: Probability
variables.description: Likelihood of the event occurring (0-1)

variables.name: Impact
variables.description: Financial impact of the event

formulas.description: Expected Monetary Value calculates the average outcome when considering the probability and impact of risks or opportunities.
formulas.whenToUse: Use for quantitative risk analysis to prioritize risks and calculate contingency reserves.

example.scenario: There's a 30% chance of equipment failure costing $50,000. Calculate EMV.

formulas.name: Standard Deviation

variables.name: Pessimistic
variables.description: Worst-case scenario estimate

variables.name: Optimistic
variables.description: Best-case scenario estimate

formulas.description: Standard Deviation measures the uncertainty range in estimates. Used to calculate confidence intervals for project completion.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to estimate the range of possible outcomes and assess risk in project estimates.

example.scenario: Optimistic = 5 days, Pessimistic = 20 days. Calculate standard deviation.

formulas.name: Point of Total Assumption
formulas.expression: PTA = ((Ceiling Price - Target Price) / Buyer Share Ratio) + Target Cost

variables.name: Ceiling Price
variables.description: Maximum price the buyer will pay

variables.name: Target Price
variables.description: Agreed target price for the contract

variables.name: Buyer Share Ratio
variables.description: Portion of cost overruns the buyer pays (as decimal)

variables.name: Target Cost
variables.description: Estimated target cost of the project

formulas.description: Point of Total Assumption is the cost at which the seller assumes all additional costs in a Fixed Price Incentive Fee contract. Above this point, profit decreases.
formulas.whenToUse: Use in FPIF contracts to determine when the seller bears all cost overruns.

example.scenario: FPIF contract: Target Cost = $100,000, Target Price = $120,000, Ceiling Price = $135,000, Buyer Share = 80%.

formulas.name: Expected Value of Perfect Information (EVPI)

variables.name: Expected Value WITH Perfect Information
variables.description: Expected value when making decisions with perfect information

variables.name: Expected Value WITHOUT Perfect Information
variables.description: Expected value when making decisions without perfect information

formulas.description: Expected Value of Perfect Information calculates the maximum amount you should pay for additional information to improve decision making.
formulas.whenToUse: Use to determine if additional research or information is worth the cost.

example.scenario: EV without perfect information = $50,000, EV with perfect information = $65,000. Calculate EVPI.
